awd_titl_txt: Closing the Loop: From Student to STEM Teacher for Idaho Schools
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation's Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship program, Closing the Loop: From Student to STEM Teacher for Idaho Schools will recruit undergraduate STEM majors and prepare them to become grade 6-12 STEM teachers in high-need, rural school districts. This Track 1 project aims to fund 65 scholarships over five years. In this project, Boise State University will collaborate with Caldwell, Jerome, Kimberly, Kuna, and Vallivue school districts to identify, recruit, and then support students interested in pursuing STEM teaching careers. During students' first two years of study, opportunities for support include an on-campus Living and Learning Community and STEM education summer internships in students' home communities. Students will complete Boise State University's four-year BS/certification program for the STEM disciplines (IDoTeach). In addition to scholarship support in their last two years of study, the project will support their transition into STEM teaching careers with an induction program that prepares new teachers to be teacher-leaders. This project aims to prepare teachers to enter the profession with knowledge of the systemic barriers that limit equitable instruction for a range of students, so that they are better advocate for the interests and needs of their increasingly diverse communities.

This proposal's merits lie in its efforts to increase the number and quality of STEM teachers for Idaho's secondary schools.  Concomitant with these efforts is the goal to identify mechanisms that support an increase in the number of teachers, particularly with respect to the needs of rural, isolated districts. The theory of action behind this proposal is that explicit attention to students' geography in recruitment, internship placement, preparation, and ongoing support will close a loop: Students will be recruited from, prepared to teach within, and ultimately hired to serve as STEM educators for their rural home communities. Program evaluation will identify features of the recruitment, preparation and retention efforts that impact the number of teachers in rural school districts. The findings have the potential to provide important information about effective strategies for recruiting and preparing highly qualified STEM teachers to teach in rural and high-needs schools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Closing the Loop: From Student to STEM Teacher for Idaho Schools was designed to address Idaho’s critical need for qualified STEM teachers in high-needs rural schools. STEM Education faculty at Boise State University aimed to recruit students from across Idaho to become STEM teachers in their communities. The project engaged and financially supported students at multiple stages of their undergraduate academic careers: recruiting them from high school into early program exploratory courses and into a Living Learning Community, supporting them through community-based internships in STEM Education, through their preservice teaching program through scholarships, and lastly, through supportive workshops during their first year of STEM teaching.

By focusing on high-need districts, the project sought to address the systemic shortage of STEM teachers in rural and underserved communities. To promote interest and retention in Boise State University's teacher education program, the project provided internships to build confidence and competency in STEM teaching. A vital aspect was ensuring that students remained connected to their communities during summer breaks. Over five years, 32 internships were awarded and 20 interns became Noyce Scholars. Internships provided hands-on teaching experience and reinforced the students' commitment to giving back to their communities as future educators. Financial barriers can often prevent talented students from pursuing STEM education careers. To address this, the project provided much-needed scholarships to students, enabling them to focus on their studies without the burden of excessive financial stress. Over the life of the award, we successfully graduated 39 Noyce Scholars. Of those, 34 are currently teaching and 13 are employed in rural Idaho schools. This outcome underscores the importance of financial aid in diversifying and strengthening the STEM teaching pipeline in Idaho and providing high quality STEM teachers for Idaho schools.To ensure that program graduates successfully transitioned into their teaching careers, the project offered ongoing support after graduation. Post-graduation support included professional development to build peer support networks aimed at helping new teachers navigate the challenges of transitioning to the classroom. Support also emphasized leadership development, preparing participants to take on roles as teacher leaders within their schools. 

While this project successfully achieved its goals by recruiting, supporting, and preparing a new generation of STEM educators, there were lessons learned as well. Recruiting high school students to become STEM teachers presents several challenges. Prior to university, many students are unaware of teaching as a viable or rewarding career option, as their own STEM teachers may not be presenting or promoting the career as a viable and rewarding option. We were able to retain our pipeline of STEM-Education students at Boise State with Noyce internships and scholarships, but we encountered challenges in recruiting the number of high school students we initially targeted. It remains a challenge to recruit students from underrepresented backgrounds and we are working hard to increase the representation of teachers to match that of Idaho’s student population, specifically focusing on recruiting Latine students. High school students may lack access to role models or resources that highlight the importance of teaching in their communities. Overcoming stereotypes about the teaching profession, addressing concerns about financial stability, and ensuring students have the academic confidence to pursue STEM subjects are critical hurdles that must be addressed to successfully recruit future STEM teachers in Idaho.
